thread.title: Rangers’ Vigneault experimenting in ‘crazy’ OT format
thread.title_full: Rangers’ Vigneault experimenting in ‘crazy’ OT format | New York Post

author: Larry Brooks
title: Rangers’ Vigneault experimenting in ‘crazy’ OT format
text:
After two games worth of experience over which the Rangers have failed to score in 8:07 of 3-on-3 overtime, Alain Vigneault was asked for his thoughts about the NHL’s newest break-the-tie gimmick.
“Crazy?” the coach responded rhetorically before the Blueshirts’ 4-1 victory over the Flames at the Garden on Sunday night. “So far we’ve only been in two, but I prefer ending games that way to a straight shootout.
“But it is crazy out there.”
The Rangers were beaten in OT by the Devils on Oct. 18, when Lee Stempniak finished a 2-on-1 immediately after Derek Stepan had hit the crossbar on an odd-man rush the other way.
Saturday, the Blueshirts and Flyers played through a scoreless 3-on-3 during which Sam Gagner lost control of the puck on a breakaway after Rick Nash and Dan Boyle had a 2-on-1 against Steve Mason that went awry.
“As soon as one guy is beaten, it’s an outnumbered situation and then if you miss the net you’re outnumbered the other way,” said Vigneault, whose team ultimately lost 3-2 in Philadelphia via a shootout. “That’s just the way it is.”
Vigneault has used four defensemen in the overtimes. Ryan McDonagh has the most time at 3:14 on five shifts while Keith Yandle has been out for 2:25 on four turns. Kevin Klein has gotten 1:57 on three shifts, Boyle 1:31 on two turns.
The Blueshirts have used eight forwards, with Stepan (2:56 on four shifts) and Rick Nash (2:41 on four) leading in ice time. Derick Brassard (2:30), Chris Kreider (2:11), Kevin Hayes (2:08) and Mats Zuccarello (2:03) have all gotten three shifts while J.T. Miller (1:12) has been out twice and Oscar Lindberg once, against Philadelphia, for 33 seconds.
“We’ve worked at it and we’ve talked a lot about philosophies,” Vigneault said. “We’ve discussed it with our guys in the American League and the coaches in the American League who played it [last year].
“I would say that generally we would go with two forwards and one defenseman, but there might be times where we might be able to set up an offensive zone faceoff play with three forwards.”
Stalberg, who suffered a presumed concussion on the unpenalized blow he took from Radko Gudas with 1:06 to go in Saturday’s second period, was sidelined on Sunday and replaced in the lineup by Emerson Etem.
There was neither a penalty called against nor supplemental discipline applied to the Flyers’ defenseman for the check that caught a reaching Stalberg in the chin.
“Viktor is feeling better,” Vigneault said. “It’s day by day.”
Jarret Stoll, 5-0 at the dots, has won 21 of 26 draws over the last three games and an off-the-charts 40 of 61 (.656) on the year.
